name: NPR
text:
A Homeland Security official has filed a whistleblower complaint saying the head of DHS instructed him to stop reporting on the Russian threat to the U.S. election because it "made President Trump look bad."
 https://t.co/jMGgXCFWYC

name: NPR
text:
In February, President Trump acknowledged the severity of the novel coronavirus to journalist Bob Woodward ‚Äî saying it's "more deadly than even your strenuous flus."

Speaking on Fox News the following month, Trump likened COVID-19 to the seasonal flu.
https://t.co/ppo0sD6rQG

name: NPR
text: Young voters may be poised for a big turnout in 2020. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, how Gen Z ‚Äî those born in or after 1996 ‚Äî are thinking about presidential candidates and today's major political parties. https://t.co/GD6RLHBOfZ

name: NPR
text:
Scientists and engineers in California are building a unique 3.2 billion-pixel camera for a telescope under construction in Chile.

The camera has already taken its first test pictures ‚Äî of some Romanesco broccoli.
https://t.co/7km2Chd1EF

name: NPR
text:
Wildfires are burning from Washington state to Southern California.

Blazes have prompted thousands of people to flee parts of Oregon and caused power outages in California ‚Äî where fires have already burned a record of over 2.3 million acres this year. 
https://t.co/KOk8nT5vg4

name: NPR
text:

name: NPR
text:
RT @theindicator: Parenting In the time of Corona isn‚Äôt easy. For many, lockdowns, working from home and educating from home have created an unsustainable situation. Many women are dropping out of the workforce entirely, others are having to power through. With @anya1anya 
https://t.co/kr0DoiLmpq

name: NPR
text:
Videos of wild boars in Germany have been going viral this summer. Groups of tourists even flocked to a lake to try to catch a glimpse of one with her piglets.

But experts warn that people must keep their distance ‚Äî for the sake of both human and animal.
https://t.co/PjAREVCZ5b

name: NPR
text:
President Trump admitted on tape to knowing the deadly nature of the coronavirus pandemic but downplaying it publicly ‚Äî saying "I wanted to always play it down," according to a new book by legendary reporter Bob Woodward.
https://t.co/C9OHlyMcDG

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Omar Ibrahim went from Aleppo to Idlib province in Syria to continue treating injuries from shelling. Now, after six years of doing surgery in a war zone, he is starting a new chapter in his life.
https://t.co/F4hbIkRIPW

name: NPR
text: Some camps that managed to successfully keep the virus at bay this summer are now offering a refuge from the virus ‚Äî to those who can afford it ‚Äî where students can live and attend classes remotely. https://t.co/ijxjz1gwL8

name: NPR
text: The Brazilian government launched benefits in April as pandemic shutdowns were battering the nation's shaky economy. As of July, they reached more than 30 million households. Now the relief is providing an unlikely popularity boost for President Bolsonaro. https://t.co/pv1esdYGqg

name: NPR
text:
RT @throughlineNPR: The USPS has played a role throughout American history - from the Declaration of Independence to today‚Äôs mail-in voting. But now, the Postal Service‚Äôs future is in danger.

How the Postal Service created the U.S. and the case for this pivotal institution: https://t.co/GC4PeCLewv https://t.co/AqGXJQwCJA

name: NPR
text: Nurses say COVID-19 patients have sometimes been housed in the same units as uninfected patients. While officials have penalized nursing homes for such failures, hospitals have seen less scrutiny. https://t.co/lzTuZsH8dW

name: NPR
text: In a whistleblower complaint, a Department of Homeland Security official says the head of DHS told him twice ‚Äî once in May and again in July ‚Äî to stop reporting on potential Russian threats to the U.S. election because it "made President Trump look bad." https://t.co/t54lCzp0XE

name: NPR
text:
If you know someone struggling with depression or thoughts of suicide, you may be wondering how to help. 

Start by reaching out.
 
Here are 9 things you can do to make a difference for someone who is struggling. #WorldSuicidePreventionDay https://t.co/uYG5BjkFqd

name: NPR
text:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Recognize the warning signs: Signs of suicide risk include changes in mood and behavior, an expert says.
 
It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ https://t.co/wWT7z9K8L2

name: NPR
text:
2Ô∏è‚É£ Reach out and ask, 'Are you OK?'
 
People who are having thoughts of suicide often feel trapped and alone, expe‚Ä¶ https://t.co/fb95Asves5

name: NPR
text:
3Ô∏è‚É£ Be direct: Ask about suicide

Some people worry this may have unintended consequences ‚Äî but experts say there‚Äôs‚Ä¶ https://t.co/msJpF2yKqm

name: NPR
text:
4Ô∏è‚É£ Assess risk and don't panic 

Suicidal feelings aren't always an emergency.
 
But how do you know if it's an immediate crisis? 
 
For help, this tool walks you through 6 questions to ask your loved one about whether they've had thoughts about suicide: https://t.co/988OkVUZbg

name: NPR
text:
5Ô∏è‚É£ If it's a crisis, stick around
 
So what if you've assessed risk and you fear your loved one is in an immediate‚Ä¶ https://t.co/cDt5DfjanK

name: NPR
text:
The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline offers this guide to the 5 action steps to take if someone you know is in imminent danger: https://t.co/oovf0hWk1j
 
If you don't feel confident about helping someone through a crisis, call its hotline at 1-800-273-8255.

name: NPR
text:
6Ô∏è‚É£ Listen and offer hope

If the person is not in immediate risk, survivors say it is still important to listen to‚Ä¶ https://t.co/cTpMzSR5Gs

name: NPR
text:
7Ô∏è‚É£ Help your loved one make a safety plan
 
When a person is not in immediate risk, it's a good time to think about preventing a future crisis.
 
The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention has a template for creating a safety plan: https://t.co/5wyFxRrm6Z

name: NPR
text:
8Ô∏è‚É£ Help them tackle the mental health care system
 
To prevent a future crisis, offer to help your loved one conne‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Loj5uQ9cTL

name: NPR
text:
9Ô∏è‚É£ Explore tools and support online
 
For those struggling to access mental health care, there are some evidence-based digital tools that can also help.
 
You can find a list of those resources at the bottom of this page: https://t.co/uYG5BjkFqd

name: NPR
text:
If you or someone you know may be considering suicide, contact:

‚Ä¢ The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-‚Ä¶ https://t.co/AwLiZtxbjr

name: NPR
text:
A record number of Americans plan to cast their ballots by mail. But experts say that shouldn't stretch the capacity of the USPS.

"They process over 400 million pieces of mail a day," one says. "There's not even half of that many voters in the country."
https://t.co/MiIbI0eK12

name: NPR
text:
RT @lilkat_bigworld: In many of the evacuated areas, humans were gone for years. Nature started to reclaim the space. And now, as humans return, they're learning to co-exist with their new animal neighbors...or not.

Here's a profile of one man and his battle with monkeys:

https://t.co/ZcOUXmf1p9

name: NPR
text:
It's here! @phoebe_bridgers' Tiny Desk (home) concert is premiering on YouTube now.

Watch live: https://t.co/cHnHwz85bE

name: NPR
text:
George Washington University says associate professor Jessica A. Krug ‚Äî a white, Jewish woman from the Midwest ‚Äî has resigned after a blog post published under her name said she'd faked several Black identities. 
 https://t.co/9hcbzVBIit
